title: Can two books have the same title? What happens? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. It is possible (and quite common) for two or more books to share the same title. It is best to avoid this situation unless you are positive that there won't be any confusion between the two titles. (Perhaps one title is very old and out of print; or the the two books are on radically different topics.) If the two books are on the same topic and are both in print at the same time, confusion may occur, leading to frustration for everyone involved in the book publishing process, including the potential book buyer. The only time when it is not possible to re-use the title of an existing book is if that title contains a trademark. Note: It becomes possible to register a trademark related to a series of books once two or more of the books in that series have been published. For example, I was able to register the trademark THE MOTHER OF ALL for the various books in my pregnancy and parenting series once first two titles, The Mother of All Pregnancy Books and The Mother of All Baby Books, had been published. I could not have attempted to trademark the books if I had only written a single title. See related document at US Patent and Trademark Office:http://www.uspto.gov/trademarks/resources/exam/examguide4-06.jsp#Single

I had been planning for a long time to read the book called "The Time Traveler's Wife.  This is the book. The plot revolves around a man with a genetic disorder which causes him to time travel frequently causing his wife to deal with his disappearances. That was all I knew about this book. I searched for this book on Scribd and began reading it. I finished it within 100 minutes. I wished that I could bash my head against the wall for it was the most terrible piece of writing in a long time. It was later I realized that I had been reading an entirely different novel of the same name.  This had been the book I read. Answering your question, it is definitely possible for two different books to have the same title. This book presumably try to trick people like me into reading it. Also, lesson learnt. Never read a book before verifying the name of the author.

Happens all the time. My bestselling book Groundswell, with Charlene Li, was not the first book of that name. It was about social media strategy, the others were about things like architecture. If the books are in the same field, the authors may have a beef with each other, but it will be hard to stake a legal claim. Book titles aren’t copyrighted or trademarked. So it’s hard to defend them.

Two books can have the same title, since the ISBN will differentiate the titles. However, it creates problems for readers trying to find a book. It also creates competition for search engines. It is hard enough to get your books ranked well, without creating unnecessary competition by naming your book the same as an already existing title.

It happens more often than you’d think. I always come up with at least a dozen titles that will work for my current work in progress, then research each one to see if it’s already taken. If not, great. I pick my favorite. If there are several, I check their publication dates and genres. If they are older books and/or a completely different genre, that’s OK with me. According to my research, there is no rule about this.

Once I choose the name for one of my books and it was published, I checked to see if people can find it on amazon and I was amazed to see how many books had the same title, “Numb “. So, logical conclusion, yes. Of course we want to be unique, but this was the word necessary to show my main character’s feelings during the saga. Legally, I have no idea. No one complained about.

Yes, it is perfectly legal to publish a book with the same title since they will have different ISBN numbers. However, there can be legal issues if you are writing a book related to a trademarked name. If you wrote a book on facebook, there is a very good chance you will be notified by the facebook legal team.
Yes they can have same title as long as they have different ISBN numbers.   Online Shopping for Electronics, Apparel, Computers, Books, DVDs & more
Yes. Titles cannot be copyrighted. Nothing happens and all books with the same title will be listed separately.

THE ABSOLUTE VALUE OF NOMINATION No, if the title of his book is original, an author may claim ownership. “A nomination is a metaphysical act of absolute value”. It is the most essential moral right of the author.
